Award.AwardTitle: Modeling, Analysis, and Computation in Nonlinear Elasticity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is focused on the mathematical prediction of mechanical behavior in highly deformable elastic structures and solids, including both soft elastic systems and brittle materials. Soft structures occur naturally in biological systems such as skin and bio-membranes and are also manufactured as thin films and elastomers. The prediction of their initial instability, such as wrinkling, and post-critical pattern formation under loading and/or growth play a prominent role in this part of the project. For brittle solids (such as ceramics or steels at low temperature), we will use a new approach to fracture, predicting the initiation and formation of cracks under incremental loading. Overall, the project aims to provide new classes of continuum-mechanical models and novel approaches to their analyses, leading to a quantitative understanding of the mechanical behavior of these systems. The work has a range of potential applications – from bio-molecular structures to engineering machines and structures. This project includes opportunities for the research training of graduate students.

Classes of nonlinear models of elastic-surface structures, soft elastic solids, and brittle solids will be analyzed. The main goals of the work are: (i) To provide properly formulated mechanics-based models. (ii) To obtain rigorous mathematical results, viz., establish existence theorems – the only true way to “ensure that the mathematical description of a physical phenomenon is meaningful” (R. Courant). (iii) To detect new phenomena. Goals (i) and (ii) inform and enrich each other; goal (iii) is enabled by goals (i) and (ii). This research is highly interdisciplinary, requiring tools and perspectives from several fields, e.g., nonlinear continuum mechanics, elliptic PDE systems, bifurcation theory, calculus of variations, numerical methods, symmetry ideas and biophysics, while providing new links between them. The project will provide new results and insights pertaining to surface-creasing formation in soft elastic solids, fracture of brittle materials, post-critical growth in elastic solids and pattern formation in lipid-bilayer structures or bio-membranes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal investigator and his coworkers studied several problems of nonlinear elasticity for thin structures and bulk solids, with applications to wrinkling of thin sheets, surface creasing of soft elastic solids, and brittle fracture of solids. The main goals of the work: (1) develop accurate, mechanics-based models; (2) provide rigorous mathematical existence results for solutions; (3) uncover new phenomena.

Major accomplishments from this grant include:

An entirely new approach to the analysis and prediction of brittle fracture:

Publications JMPS 2021 (with Rosakis & Alyanak), J. Elast. 2023 (with Gupta), and JMPS 2024 (with Paroni & Rosakis), represent a significant breakthrough in the analysis of brittle fracture. The new approach overcomes the problem of discontinuous deformations without additional field variables, such as damage or phase-field variables, or pre-existing cracks. The key is the employment of the inverse deformation, which can be extended to be a piecewise smooth mapping even when the original deformation has discontinuities describing cracks opening.  As demonstarted in the above-mentioned works, the model can predict the nucleation and development of actual cracks (breakage) in loaded specimens.

New existence theorems for highly deformable thin elastic surfaces:

Although many different models have been proposed in the literature, and in spite of an abundance of numerical evidence (including availability in commercially available software), there is little in the way of existence theorems for finitely-strained, thin elastic surfaces.  Such theorems are the true test of the validity of a model. In publications J. Elast. 2023 (with Nair), ZAMP 2023, Quart. Appl. Math. 2024 (with Nair) we propose, successfully employ and/or incorporate a new constitutive hypothesis for nonlinearly elastic membranes deforming in 3-dimensional space. The proposed energy density is a convex function of the strain pair comprising the deformation gradient and the local area ratio. But as a function of the deformation gradient alone, it posseses no convexity properties except when the membrane is confined to deform in a plane (in which case, it is 2D polyconvex). Combined with bending energy, i.e., in shell theory, our membrane model leads to existence theorems accounting for wrinkling phenomena under high stretching. This is a new contribution.

Each class of problems studied has direct and important connections to basic science and technology. For example, thin-membrane structures are ubiquitous in both biological and manufactured systems. Moreover, a predictive understanding of fracture in solids is vital for safety in engineering structures. With the support from this grant, one student completed his PhD, another is working toward his PhD, and nine papers were published in highly respected, peer-reviewed journals.
